text: in Italy you need a whole pig to make
porchetta I have a streamlined version
using pork chops for this recipe it's
really important to get nice thick pork
chops these are about an inch and a half
and I'm gonna Pat them dry and then I'm
gonna cut a little pocket in them and
that pocket is where all that good
porchetta seasoning is gonna go get your
sharpest paring knife for this because
if the knife isn't sharp enough it's not
gonna go into the pork and you want to
start on the fat side about halfway in
the middle there and just go across and
that's it and then you do the same thing
on your other child I think one of the
things that sets chefs cooking apart
from you know home cooks is that we
don't season our meats enough we just
think it's gonna be too salty but it's
not be really generous make sure to
season inside the pocket because you
want that to be nice and salty too and
then if you can let your meat sit for
about 10 minutes even up to a half an
hour with the salt on it it just helps
it penetrate and then it'll cook more
evenly what makes a porchetta in part is
the seasonings it's the herbs it's the
garlic it's the lemon and it's the
fennel so I've got fennel fronds here
this is just the green fluffy part on
top of a fennel I've cut them off you
can use the fennel bulb for something
else save it for another recipe or make
it into a salad to serve on the side I'm
using all these little very fine thin
green bits here the leaves but I'm also
gonna use the tender stems because those
add great flavor and they'll just chop
right up I'm looking for about two
tablespoons but you can eyeball it and
then i'm also using rosemary rosemary is
a favorite in italy its favorite and
pajetta
and i have fennel seeds right here I've
just given them a light crack with a
mortar and pestle red chili flakes oh
the red chili flakes this is the zest of
one lemon
I finally grated it and garlic mashed to
a paste with a little bit of salt just
enough olive oil to kind of bind
everything together
about a tablespoon and mix it all up use
your hands for this because you're about
to use your hands to stuff it into the
pockets so no point in dirtying a spoon
and then just stuff the pocket that you
made with your nice herb mixture this
by the way is a great technique for any
kind of stuffing if you like spinach and
cheese you could stuff it in your pork
chop seasoned breadcrumbs mushrooms and
I'm gonna rub just a little of this on
the outside heat up a large ovenproof
skillet over high heat add some olive
oil let it heat up then sear the pork
chops for about five minutes per side or
until they're golden brown put the
skillet in the oven and cook them until
they're just done 135 on a meat
thermometer these are done took about
five minutes in the oven and they are
gorgeous I could make a sauce out of all
those beautiful brown bits on the bottom
of the pan but I don't even need to cook
this pork Etta has so much flavor let
him sit for a couple of minutes about
ten minutes to reabsorb all the juices
and you should be just about there I'm
gonna just put them on a cutting board
instead of plates just because it's a
pretty way to serve them you pour a
little bit of this yummy juice right on
top let people just squeeze lemon on top
if they want it to be extra lemony and
then just for a little bit of color and
also this gives a clue to what's inside
now porchetta style pork chops I've got
all the garlicky herbal flavor of a real
Italian porchetta but you know you don't
have to round up a whole thing
